Installation and Compilation Instructions (Source Code Version)

You should have PowerShell 2.0 installed and working before installing the PowerTools for OpenXML.

1.       If you have not done so already, install the OpenXml SDK 2.0. You can download it from http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=5124.

2.       Extract the contents of the compressed file and open the solution in Visual Studio or Visual C# Express Edition. Make sure you are set to compile a release version and compile it.

3.       Locate the files “OpenXmlPowerTools.dll” in the release build folder and “OpenXmlPowerTools.dll-Help.xml” in the project folder. Now create a new folder named “OpenXmlPowerTools” in the “modules” folder for PowerShell. Use the “windowspowershell” folder in the user documents folder for local installation or use the “windowspowershell\v1.0” folder in your windows System32 folder for global installation. You may need to create the “windowspowershell” and “modules” folders, if they do not already exist.

4.       If you have not already done so, you will need to change the execution policy for PowerShell to allow execution of external cmdlets. For example, Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted should work. Run the PowerShell as administrator in order to make this change. This is the only command that requires administrator permissions and it needs to be done only once.

5.       Whenever you run the PowerShell, you will need to import the module with this command: Import-Module OpenXmlPowerTools. You can put that command in the “profile.ps1” file in the “windowspowershell” or “windowspowershell\v1.0” folders, depending of if you want to change the local or global profile script.

Changes to version 2.2

·         Added Section parameter to Header and Footer cmdlets.

·         Changed installation instructions to use module method.

Changes to version 2.1

·         Accept-OpenXmlChange has been renamed to Edit-OpenXmlChange to eliminate the non-standard verb.

·         The following cmdlets are new in this version: Confirm-OpenXmlValid, Merge-OpenXmlDocumentComment, Remove-OpenXmlMarkup, Set-OpenXmlString

·         Major enhancements have been made to the following cmdlets: Add-OpenXmlDocumentTOA, Add-OpenXmlDocumentTOC, Add-OpenXmlDocumentTOF, Export-OpenXmlToHtml, Merge-OpenXmlDocument

·         Minor enhancements have been made to all other cmdlets. Most parameters have changed position and some have changed names for more consistency and descriptiveness.

Changes to version 1.1.1

·         For Merge-OpenXmlDocument, added code to detect when the same image is being referenced to avoid creating duplicate image parts.

·         For Merge-OpenXmlDocument, improved the “keep sections” functionality.

·         For Merge-OpenXmlDocument, added checks when finding the current maximum ID. The previous version would fail if the document had a part (e.g. Numbering), but there were no elements in the part.

·         For Merge-OpenXmlDocument, it would fail if the document did not have a Styles part or a FontTable part. That has been fixed.

Changes to version 1.1

·         The following cmdlets are new in this version: Add-OpenXmlSpreadSheetTable cmdlet, Merge-OpenXmlDocument, Remove-OpenXmlPersonalInformation, Select-OpenXmlString, Set-OpenXmlSpreadSheetCellStyle, Set-OpenXmlSpreadSheetCellValue, Set-OpenXmlSpreadSheetColumnWidth and Split-OpenXmlDocument. (NOTE: The new Spreadsheet cmdlets may be replaced or superceded by a more general cmdlet in the future.)

·         Improved the process for handling images in the Export-OpenXmlToHtml cmdlet.

·         Fixed a bug in Set-OpenXmlWatermark that caused it to work incorrectly under some circumstances.

·         The original test scripts and documents have been removed from the distribution.

Changes to code in version 2.2

·         Deleted source code modules that are no longer used.

Changes to code in version 2.1

·         Major changes have been made to the code.

·         All document files are kept closed except when reading or writing. Open XML documents are now always based on a MemoryStream which is closed as soon as processing is complete. The document data is passed around methods and piped between cmdlets using the OpenXmlPowerToolsDocument, which is only a byte array and, optionally, the original file name of the document file. This eliminates problems with making sure that document files are closed properly.

·         All of the “Accessor” classes have become static with static methods to perform operations on documents. This is just a step toward better code organization, but it does eliminate the creation of a number of objects that were not really necessary.

·         The cmdlet classes are now derived from one of three base cmdlet classes depending on the type of functionality: Read-Only, Modifier or Creator. Read-Only cmdlets read documents, but never modify them. Modifiers make modifications to documents. Creators create a new document that must be saved or piped.

·         Parameter definitions are being simplified, but that work is not complete. Positions of parameters are more consistent.

Changes to code in version 1.1.1

·         The only significant change is the code to eliminate duplicate images. There is a new support class used to store and compare images in memory during the document merge. The list of images is then passed through all the functions that may have image references.

Changes to code in version 1.1

·         Steps are being taken to eliminate, or greatly reduce the size of, the WordProcessingDocument class in the PowerTools namespace. As an intermediate step, the name of that class has been changed to PTWordProcessingDocument to avoid confusion with the WordProcessingDocument class in the OpenXml SDK.

·         Added DocumentBuilder.cs: This file contains the new code for extracting paragraphs(elements) from a document and creating new documents from those paragraphs. The Merge-OpenXmlDocument and Split-OpenXmlDocument cmdlets rely on this code. It was also designed to be usable from other applications along with DocumentExtensions.cs.

·         Added DocumentExtensions.cs: This file contains the new code for handling XDocuments that are loaded from the OpenXml package. This code was previously in the OpenXml.PowerTools.OpenXmlDocument class.

·         Added PowerToolsExtensions.cs: This is the new coding style for implementing functionality in the PowerTools. Currently, it contains support code for the new cmdlets Select-OpenXmlString and Remove-OpenXmlPersonalInformation.

·         The full file name was added to OpenXml.PowerTools.OpenXmlDocument in order to provide that information as part of the output from Select-OpenXmlString.
